meta.title: Physics MCQs
meta.description: Practice questions on Kinematics, Laws of Motion, Work, Power, Energy, and many more Physics topics.
meta.keywords: physics, mcqs, quiz, kinematics, laws of motion, gravitation, thermodynamics, optics, electricity, magnetism, modern physics

questions.q: Which of the following is a scalar quantity?
questions.ex: Speed is a scalar quantity as it only has magnitude, while displacement, velocity, and acceleration are vector quantities.

questions.q: A car accelerates from rest to 20 m/s in 5 seconds. What is its average acceleration?
questions.ex: Acceleration = (Change in velocity) / Time = (20 m/s - 0 m/s) / 5 s = 4 m/s².

questions.q: In projectile motion, neglecting air resistance, the horizontal component of velocity remains:
questions.ex: In projectile motion, without air resistance, there is no horizontal force acting on the projectile, so its horizontal velocity remains constant.

questions.q: The rate of change of displacement is known as:
questions.ex: Velocity is defined as the rate of change of displacement.

questions.q: An object moves 10 m East and then 5 m West. What is its total displacement?
questions.ex: Displacement is the straight-line distance from the starting point to the ending point. 10m East - 5m West = 5m East.

questions.q: Newton's First Law of Motion is also known as the Law of:
questions.ex: Newton's First Law states that an object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force. This describes inertia.

questions.q: A force of 10 N acts on an object of mass 2 kg. What is the acceleration produced?
questions.ex: According to Newton's Second Law, F = ma, so a = F/m = 10 N / 2 kg = 5 m/s².

questions.q: When a gun is fired, the bullet moves forward, and the gun recoils backward. This illustrates which of Newton's Laws?
questions.ex: This is an example of Newton's Third Law: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

questions.q: The net force acting on an object moving with a constant velocity is:
questions.ex: If an object is moving with constant velocity, its acceleration is zero. According to Newton's Second Law (F=ma), if acceleration is zero, the net force must also be zero.

questions.q: Which force opposes the relative motion of surfaces in contact?
questions.ex: Frictional force is the force that opposes the relative motion or tendency of such motion between two surfaces in contact.

questions.q: What is the SI unit of work?
questions.ex: The SI unit of work is the Joule (J).

questions.q: A force of 50 N pushes a box 10 meters in the direction of the force. How much work is done?
questions.ex: Work done (W) = Force (F) × Distance (d) = 50 N × 10 m = 500 J.

questions.q: Power is defined as the rate at which:
questions.ex: Power is the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred.

questions.q: Which of the following is a form of mechanical energy?
questions.ex: Mechanical energy includes kinetic energy (energy of motion) and potential energy (stored energy due to position).

questions.q: According to the Law of Conservation of Energy:
options: Energy can be created but not destroyed
Energy can be destroyed but not created
Energy can neither be created nor destroyed, only transformed
Energy is always lost in transformations
questions.ex: The Law of Conservation of Energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, but it can be transformed from one form to another.

questions.q: For an object moving in a uniform circular motion, its speed is constant, but its ______ is changing.
questions.ex: In uniform circular motion, the speed is constant, but the direction of motion is continuously changing, which means velocity (a vector) is changing.

questions.q: The force responsible for keeping an object in a circular path is called the:
questions.ex: Centripetal force is the net force that acts on an object to keep it moving in a circular path.

questions.q: What is the direction of centripetal force?
options: Perpendicular to the plane of motion
questions.ex: Centripetal force always acts towards the center of the circular path.

questions.q: If the radius of a circular path is doubled while the speed remains constant, how does the centripetal force change?
questions.ex: Centripetal force F = mv²/r. If r doubles, F halves.

questions.q: Angular velocity is typically measured in:
questions.ex: The SI unit for angular velocity is radians per second (rad/s).

questions.q: The rotational equivalent of force in linear motion is:
questions.ex: Torque is the rotational equivalent of force, causing angular acceleration.

questions.q: What is the SI unit of torque?
questions.ex: The SI unit of torque is the Newton-meter (N·m).

questions.q: The resistance of an object to changes in its rotational motion is called:
questions.ex: Moment of inertia is the rotational equivalent of mass, representing resistance to changes in angular velocity.

questions.q: Which principle states that the total angular momentum of a closed system remains constant?
questions.ex: The principle of conservation of angular momentum states that the total angular momentum of a system is conserved if no external torque acts on it.

questions.q: A larger moment of inertia means an object is harder to:
questions.ex: A larger moment of inertia indicates greater resistance to changes in rotational motion, meaning it's harder to start or stop its rotation.

questions.q: Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation states that the gravitational force between two objects is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers. What is the proportionality constant called?
questions.ex: The proportionality constant in Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation is the Universal Gravitational Constant (G).

questions.q: The acceleration due to gravity on the Moon is less than on Earth primarily because:
options: The Moon is further from the Sun
The Moon has a smaller mass
questions.ex: The acceleration due to gravity (g) depends on the mass of the planet (g = GM/R²). Since the Moon has a much smaller mass than Earth, its 'g' value is lower.

questions.q: Which of Kepler's Laws describes that planets sweep out equal areas in equal times?
questions.ex: Kepler's Second Law, also known as the Law of Equal Areas, states that a line joining a planet and the Sun sweeps out equal areas during equal intervals of time.

questions.q: A satellite in orbit around Earth is continuously falling towards Earth. Why does it not hit the Earth?
options: It is beyond Earth's gravitational pull
It has a high tangential velocity
It is pushed by solar winds
It is in a geostationary orbit
questions.ex: A satellite remains in orbit because its high tangential velocity is large enough to continuously 'miss' the Earth while being pulled by gravity, effectively falling around it.

questions.q: If the distance between two masses is doubled, the gravitational force between them will be:
questions.ex: Gravitational force F is inversely proportional to r². If r doubles, r² quadruples, so F becomes one-fourth.

questions.q: Which of the following is a measure of the average kinetic energy of the particles in a substance?
questions.ex: Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of the atoms or molecules in a substance.

questions.q: What is the SI unit of temperature?
questions.ex: The SI unit of temperature is the Kelvin (K).

questions.q: Heat is a form of energy that flows from a region of ______ temperature to a region of ______ temperature.
questions.ex: Heat naturally flows from an area of higher temperature to an area of lower temperature.

questions.q: The amount of heat required to raise the temperature of 1 kg of a substance by 1 Kelvin (or 1 degree Celsius) is called its:
questions.ex: Specific heat capacity is the amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of a unit mass of a substance by a unit temperature increment.

questions.q: What happens to the temperature of a substance during a phase change (e.g., melting or boiling)?
questions.ex: During a phase change, the energy added or removed is used to break or form bonds, not to increase the kinetic energy of particles, so the temperature remains constant.

questions.q: The First Law of Thermodynamics is essentially a restatement of the conservation of:
questions.ex: The First Law of Thermodynamics states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred or changed from one form to another.

questions.q: Which law states that heat cannot spontaneously flow from a colder body to a hotter body?
questions.ex: This is one of the statements of the Second Law of Thermodynamics (Clausius statement).

questions.q: The measure of disorder or randomness in a system is called:
questions.ex: Entropy is a thermodynamic property that measures the degree of disorder or randomness in a system.

questions.q: The Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics deals with the concept of:
questions.ex: The Zeroth Law states that if two systems are each in thermal equilibrium with a third system, then they are in thermal equilibrium with each other, thus defining thermal equilibrium.

questions.q: According to the Third Law of Thermodynamics, the entropy of a perfect crystal at absolute zero (0 Kelvin) is:
questions.ex: The Third Law of Thermodynamics states that the entropy of a perfect crystalline substance is zero at absolute zero temperature.

questions.q: When a substance is heated, its particles generally vibrate with greater amplitude, leading to an increase in its volume. This phenomenon is known as:
questions.ex: Thermal expansion is the tendency of matter to change in volume in response to a change in temperature.

questions.q: Linear expansion refers to the change in ______ of a material due to temperature change.
questions.ex: Linear expansion specifically describes the change in length of a solid material.

questions.q: Bridges are built with expansion joints to accommodate:
questions.ex: Expansion joints allow the bridge material to expand and contract with temperature changes without causing stress and damage.

questions.q: Water shows anomalous expansion between 0°C and 4°C. When heated in this range, its volume:
questions.ex: Unlike most substances, water contracts when heated from 0°C to 4°C, reaching its maximum density at 4°C. Above 4°C, it expands normally.

questions.q: The coefficient of linear expansion is defined as the fractional change in length per unit change in:
questions.ex: The coefficient of linear expansion quantifies how much a material's length changes per degree Celsius or Kelvin change in temperature.

questions.q: Which mode of heat transfer involves the direct transfer of kinetic energy between particles in contact?
questions.ex: Conduction is the transfer of heat through direct contact, primarily in solids.

questions.q: Heat transfer in fluids (liquids and gases) primarily occurs through the movement of the fluid itself. This process is called:
questions.ex: Convection involves the transfer of heat by the movement of heated fluid particles.

questions.q: Which method of heat transfer does not require a medium for heat to be transferred?
questions.ex: Radiation is the transfer of heat through electromagnetic waves and can occur through a vacuum (e.g., heat from the sun).

questions.q: A shiny, light-colored surface is a good ______ and a poor ______ of thermal radiation.
questions.ex: Shiny, light-colored surfaces reflect thermal radiation well and absorb/emit it poorly.

questions.q: The process by which heat is transferred from the sun to the Earth is primarily:
questions.ex: Heat from the sun travels through the vacuum of space to Earth via radiation (electromagnetic waves).

questions.q: In Simple Harmonic Motion (SHM), the restoring force is directly proportional to the displacement from the equilibrium position and acts in the opposite direction. This is described by:
questions.ex: Hooke's Law (F = -kx) describes the restoring force in an ideal spring-mass system, which undergoes SHM.

questions.q: Which of the following is constant for an object undergoing SHM?
questions.ex: The period (and frequency) of SHM is constant for a given oscillating system, assuming no damping.

questions.q: At which point in its oscillation does an object in SHM have maximum speed?
options: Midway between equilibrium and maximum displacement
questions.ex: The speed of an object in SHM is maximum when it passes through its equilibrium position.

questions.q: What is the phase difference between displacement and velocity in SHM?
questions.ex: Velocity is 90 degrees (π/2 radians) out of phase with displacement; when displacement is maximum, velocity is zero, and vice-versa.

questions.q: A simple pendulum's period depends on:
questions.ex: For small angles, the period of a simple pendulum T = 2π√(L/g), where L is the length of the pendulum.

questions.q: A wave that requires a medium for its propagation is called a:
questions.ex: Mechanical waves (like sound waves, water waves) require a material medium to travel through.

questions.q: In a transverse wave, the particles of the medium oscillate ______ to the direction of wave propagation.
questions.ex: In a transverse wave, the displacement of the medium is perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation.

questions.q: The distance between two consecutive crests or troughs in a wave is called the:
questions.ex: Wavelength (λ) is the spatial period of a wave, the distance over which the wave's shape repeats.

questions.q: The number of complete oscillations or cycles per unit time is called the:
questions.ex: Frequency (f) is the number of cycles or vibrations per second.

questions.q: Which of the following phenomena best describes the bending of waves around obstacles?
questions.ex: Diffraction is the bending of waves as they pass around the edge of an obstacle or through a small opening.

questions.q: Sound waves are examples of:
questions.ex: Sound waves are longitudinal waves because the particles of the medium vibrate parallel to the direction of wave propagation.

questions.q: The speed of sound is generally fastest in which medium?
questions.ex: Sound travels fastest in solids because particles are most densely packed and transmit vibrations more efficiently.

questions.q: The characteristic of sound that depends on its amplitude is:
questions.ex: Loudness (or intensity) of sound is directly related to its amplitude.

questions.q: What is the range of audible frequencies for a typical human ear?
questions.ex: The human ear can generally perceive sound frequencies between 20 Hz and 20,000 Hz.

questions.q: Sound waves cannot travel through:
questions.ex: Sound waves are mechanical waves and require a material medium to propagate, so they cannot travel through a vacuum.

questions.q: Resonance occurs when the frequency of a driving force matches the ______ of an oscillating system.
questions.ex: Resonance is a phenomenon where a vibrating system or external force drives another system to oscillate with greater amplitude at a specific or resonant frequency.

questions.q: The Tacoma Narrows Bridge collapse is a classic example of destruction due to:
questions.ex: The bridge collapsed due to aeroelastic flutter, which involved resonance with wind forces.

questions.q: In an RLC series circuit, resonance occurs when:
questions.ex: In an RLC series circuit, resonance occurs when the inductive reactance (XL) equals the capacitive reactance (XC), leading to maximum current.

questions.q: Musical instruments often use resonance to:
questions.ex: Musical instruments are designed to resonate at specific frequencies to produce clear and amplified musical notes.

questions.q: What happens to the amplitude of oscillations at resonance?
questions.ex: At resonance, if damping is low, the amplitude of oscillations can increase dramatically.

questions.q: The Doppler Effect describes the change in observed ______ of a wave due to relative motion between the source and the observer.
questions.ex: The Doppler Effect is the change in frequency (and wavelength) of a wave in relation to an observer who is moving relative to the wave source.

questions.q: When a police siren approaches you, its pitch appears to be:
questions.ex: As the source (siren) approaches, the sound waves are compressed, leading to a higher observed frequency and thus a higher pitch.

questions.q: If a light source is moving away from an observer, the observed light will be shifted towards the red end of the spectrum. This phenomenon is called:
questions.ex: Redshift occurs when light from an object is observed to be shifted toward longer wavelengths (lower frequencies) due to the object moving away from the observer.

questions.q: Which of the following applications uses the Doppler effect?
questions.ex: Weather radar uses the Doppler effect to measure the speed and direction of precipitation and storms.

questions.q: For the Doppler effect to be observed, there must be relative motion between the ______ and the ______.
questions.ex: The Doppler effect arises from the relative motion between the wave source and the observer.

questions.q: The bouncing back of light when it strikes a surface is called:
questions.ex: Reflection is the change in direction of a wave at a boundary between two different media so that the wave returns into the medium from which it originated.

questions.q: According to the Law of Reflection, the angle of incidence is equal to the angle of:
questions.ex: The Law of Reflection states that the angle of incidence (angle between the incident ray and the normal) equals the angle of reflection (angle between the reflected ray and the normal).

questions.q: The bending of light as it passes from one medium to another is called:
questions.ex: Refraction is the change in direction of a wave passing from one medium to another or from a gradual change in the medium.

questions.q: Which property of light changes when it undergoes refraction?
questions.ex: When light refracts, its speed and wavelength change, but its frequency remains constant.

questions.q: When light passes from a denser medium to a rarer medium, it bends ______ the normal.
questions.ex: When light goes from a denser to a rarer medium (e.g., water to air), it speeds up and bends away from the normal.

questions.q: Which type of mirror produces only virtual, upright, and diminished images?
questions.ex: A convex mirror always produces virtual, upright, and diminished images, regardless of the object's position.

questions.q: For a concave mirror, if an object is placed at the center of curvature (C), the image formed will be:
questions.ex: When an object is placed at C of a concave mirror, the image is formed at C, is real, inverted, and of the same size as the object.

questions.q: Which type of lens is used to correct hypermetropia (farsightedness)?
questions.ex: Hypermetropia is corrected using a convex (converging) lens to converge light rays before they enter the eye, allowing them to focus on the retina.

questions.q: The power of a lens is measured in:
questions.ex: The power of a lens is measured in Diopters (D), which is the reciprocal of the focal length in meters.

questions.q: An object placed at the principal focus of a converging lens will produce an image at:
options: The focal point on the other side
questions.ex: When an object is placed at the principal focus of a converging lens, the refracted rays become parallel, forming an image at infinity.

questions.q: The phenomenon where two or more waves superimpose to form a resultant wave of greater, lower, or same amplitude is called:
questions.ex: Interference is the superposition of two or more waves resulting in a new wave pattern.

questions.q: Young's Double-Slit Experiment demonstrates the wave nature of light through:
questions.ex: Young's experiment produces an interference pattern (bright and dark fringes), providing strong evidence for the wave nature of light.

questions.q: The bending of light waves as they pass through a narrow aperture or around obstacles is known as:
questions.ex: Diffraction is the phenomenon where waves spread out as a result of passing through a narrow aperture or across an edge.

questions.q: Which phenomenon confirms the transverse nature of light waves?
questions.ex: Polarization, which involves restricting the vibrations of light waves to a single plane, can only occur with transverse waves.

questions.q: When light passes through a polaroid filter, its intensity is reduced by half. This is due to:
questions.ex: An ideal polaroid filter transmits only the component of unpolarized light that vibrates in its transmission axis, thus reducing the intensity by half.

questions.q: Which optical instrument uses a combination of two convex lenses to produce a magnified image of distant objects?
questions.ex: A refracting telescope uses an objective lens and an eyepiece lens (both convex) to magnify distant objects.

questions.q: The primary function of the objective lens in a compound microscope is to form a:
questions.ex: The objective lens of a compound microscope forms a real, inverted, and magnified image of the object, which then acts as the object for the eyepiece.

questions.q: What is the function of the diaphragm in a camera or microscope?
options: To control the amount of light entering
questions.ex: The diaphragm (or aperture) controls the amount of light passing through the lens, affecting brightness and depth of field.

questions.q: The magnifying glass is essentially a:
questions.ex: A magnifying glass is a simple convex lens used to produce a magnified virtual image of an object placed within its focal length.

questions.q: Astigmatism, a common vision defect, is corrected by using which type of lens?
questions.ex: Astigmatism, caused by an irregularly shaped cornea or lens, is corrected with cylindrical lenses which have different curvatures in different planes.

questions.q: Which law describes the force between two point charges?
questions.ex: Coulomb's Law quantifies the electrostatic force between two charged particles.

questions.q: The SI unit of electric charge is the:
questions.ex: The SI unit of electric charge is the Coulomb (C).

questions.q: Electric field lines point in the direction that a ______ charge would move.
questions.ex: Electric field lines are conventionally drawn to originate from positive charges and terminate on negative charges, indicating the direction of force on a positive test charge.

questions.q: Materials that allow electric charge to flow easily through them are called:
questions.ex: Conductors are materials (like metals) with free electrons that allow electric charge to move freely.

questions.q: What is the electric potential at a point in an electric field?
options: The work done per unit charge to move a charge from that point to infinity
The force per unit charge at that point
The work done per unit charge to move a charge from infinity to that point
questions.ex: Electric potential is defined as the work done in bringing a unit positive charge from infinity to a point in an electric field.

questions.q: The flow of electric charge is known as:
questions.ex: Electric current is defined as the rate of flow of electric charge.

questions.q: What is the SI unit of electric current?
questions.ex: The SI unit of electric current is the Ampere (A).

questions.q: Ohm's Law states that V = IR. What does 'R' represent?
questions.ex: In Ohm's Law, R stands for electrical resistance, which opposes the flow of current.

questions.q: In a series circuit, what remains constant across all components?
questions.ex: In a series circuit, the current is the same through every component.

questions.q: What is the SI unit of electrical resistance?
questions.ex: The SI unit of electrical resistance is the Ohm (Ω).

questions.q: A capacitor stores:
questions.ex: A capacitor is an electronic component that stores electric charge on its plates.

questions.q: What is the SI unit of capacitance?
questions.ex: The SI unit of capacitance is the Farad (F).

questions.q: In a parallel circuit, what remains constant across all components?
questions.ex: In a parallel circuit, the voltage (potential difference) is the same across all parallel branches.

questions.q: Which law states that the sum of currents entering a junction equals the sum of currents leaving it?
questions.ex: Kirchhoff's Current Law (KCL) is based on the conservation of charge at a junction.

questions.q: What happens to the total capacitance when capacitors are connected in series?
questions.ex: When capacitors are connected in series, the reciprocal of the total capacitance is the sum of the reciprocals of individual capacitances, meaning the total capacitance decreases.

subcategories.title: Magnetism and Magnetic Effects of Current

questions.q: Magnetic field lines emerge from the ______ pole and enter the ______ pole of a magnet.
questions.ex: Conventionally, magnetic field lines originate from the North pole and terminate at the South pole.

questions.q: What is the SI unit of magnetic field strength (magnetic flux density)?
questions.ex: The SI unit of magnetic field strength is the Tesla (T).

questions.q: Which rule helps to determine the direction of the magnetic field around a current-carrying wire?
questions.ex: The Right-Hand Grip (or Right-Hand Rule) is used to find the direction of the magnetic field produced by a current-carrying wire.

questions.q: The force experienced by a current-carrying conductor placed in a magnetic field is described by:
questions.ex: The Lorentz force describes the force exerted by a magnetic field on a moving electric charge or on a current-carrying conductor.

questions.q: Materials that are strongly attracted to magnets are called:
questions.ex: Ferromagnetic materials (like iron, nickel, cobalt) are strongly attracted to magnetic fields and can retain magnetism.

questions.q: Which law states that a changing magnetic flux through a coil induces an electromotive force (EMF)?
questions.ex: Faraday's Law of Induction is the fundamental law of electromagnetism that predicts how a magnetic field will interact with an electric circuit to produce an electromotive force (EMF).

questions.q: Lenz's Law helps to determine the ______ of the induced current.
questions.ex: Lenz's Law states that the direction of the induced current is such that it opposes the change in magnetic flux that produced it.

questions.q: Which device works on the principle of electromagnetic induction to change AC voltage levels?
questions.ex: A transformer uses mutual induction between two coils to step up or step down AC voltages.

questions.q: When a magnet is moved towards a coil, what happens to the coil?
options: An electric current is induced in it
questions.ex: Moving a magnet near a coil changes the magnetic flux through the coil, inducing an electromotive force (EMF) and hence a current, according to Faraday's Law.

questions.q: What is the SI unit of magnetic flux?
questions.ex: The SI unit of magnetic flux is the Weber (Wb).

questions.q: In an AC circuit, the current and voltage continuously change direction and magnitude over time, typically following a ______ pattern.
questions.ex: Alternating current (AC) typically exhibits a sinusoidal waveform, meaning its magnitude and direction vary cyclically.

questions.q: What is the primary advantage of AC over DC for power transmission over long distances?
questions.ex: AC voltage can be easily stepped up or down using transformers, which is crucial for efficient long-distance power transmission (high voltage, low current to minimize power loss).

questions.q: The effective value of an AC current or voltage is known as its ______ value.
questions.ex: The RMS (Root Mean Square) value is the effective value of AC current or voltage, representing the equivalent DC value that would produce the same heating effect.

questions.q: Which component in an AC circuit introduces opposition to current flow that depends on the frequency?
questions.ex: Both capacitors (capacitive reactance) and inductors (inductive reactance) introduce frequency-dependent opposition to current flow in AC circuits.

questions.q: What is the typical frequency of AC power in many parts of the world (e.g., Pakistan, Europe)?
questions.ex: Many regions, including Pakistan and most of Europe, use a 50 Hz AC power supply.

questions.q: The photoelectric effect is the emission of electrons when ______ shines on a material.
questions.ex: The photoelectric effect is the phenomenon of electron emission from a material when light of sufficient frequency shines on it.

questions.q: Which scientist explained the photoelectric effect by proposing that light consists of discrete packets of energy called photons?
questions.ex: Albert Einstein explained the photoelectric effect in 1905, for which he received the Nobel Prize, by postulating the existence of photons.

questions.q: The minimum frequency of light required to eject electrons from a metal surface is called the:
questions.ex: The threshold frequency is the minimum frequency of incident radiation below which no photoelectrons are emitted, regardless of the intensity.

questions.q: What happens to the kinetic energy of emitted photoelectrons if the intensity of incident light is increased (keeping frequency constant)?
questions.ex: The kinetic energy of photoelectrons depends only on the frequency of light and the work function of the metal, not on the intensity. Increased intensity only increases the number of emitted electrons.

questions.q: The energy of a photon is directly proportional to its:
questions.ex: The energy of a photon (E) is given by E = hf, where h is Planck's constant and f is the frequency. So, energy is directly proportional to frequency.

questions.q: Which model of the atom proposed that electrons orbit the nucleus in discrete energy levels?
questions.ex: Niels Bohr proposed the model of the atom with electrons orbiting in quantized energy shells.

questions.q: The atomic number (Z) of an element represents the number of ______ in its nucleus.
questions.ex: The atomic number (Z) uniquely identifies an element and is equal to the number of protons in the nucleus.

questions.q: Isotopes are atoms of the same element that have the same number of protons but different numbers of:
questions.ex: Isotopes are atoms with the same atomic number (protons) but different mass numbers (due to different numbers of neutrons).

questions.q: Which subatomic particle carries a negative electric charge?
questions.ex: Electrons carry a fundamental negative charge.

questions.q: The mass number (A) of an atom is the sum of the number of ______ and ______ in its nucleus.
questions.ex: The mass number (A) is the total number of protons and neutrons (nucleons) in an atomic nucleus.

questions.q: Which type of radiation consists of high-energy electromagnetic waves?
questions.ex: Gamma rays are a form of electromagnetic radiation (photons) of very high frequency and energy.

questions.q: The process by which a heavy nucleus splits into two or more smaller nuclei, releasing a large amount of energy, is called:
questions.ex: Nuclear fission is the process of splitting a heavy atomic nucleus, typically initiated by a neutron, releasing energy.

questions.q: The time taken for half of the radioactive nuclei in a sample to decay is called its:
questions.ex: Half-life is the characteristic time period for radioactive decay.

questions.q: Which process powers the sun and other stars?
questions.ex: The sun and stars generate energy through nuclear fusion, combining light nuclei (like hydrogen) into heavier ones.

questions.q: Beta decay involves the emission of an electron or a positron from the nucleus. This process converts a neutron into a proton (or vice versa) and conserves:
options: Both mass number and atomic number
Neither mass number nor atomic number
questions.ex: In beta decay, the mass number (A) remains unchanged, while the atomic number (Z) changes by +1 (for beta-minus) or -1 (for beta-plus) to conserve charge and nucleon number.

subcategories.title: Dual Nature of Matter and Radiation

questions.q: The concept that light can behave as both a wave and a particle is known as:
questions.ex: Wave-particle duality is a fundamental concept in quantum mechanics, stating that every particle or quantum entity may be partly described in terms of waves and partly in terms of particles.

questions.q: De Broglie wavelength is associated with:
questions.ex: De Broglie proposed that all particles, not just photons, have wave-like properties, with a wavelength inversely proportional to their momentum.

questions.q: The Davisson-Germer experiment provided experimental evidence for the wave nature of:
questions.ex: The Davisson-Germer experiment demonstrated that electrons exhibit wave-like behavior through diffraction.

questions.q: The energy of a photon is given by the equation E = hf. What does 'h' represent?
questions.ex: In quantum mechanics, 'h' is Planck's constant, a fundamental physical constant relating the energy of a photon to its frequency.

questions.q: Which of the following phenomena supports the particle nature of light?
questions.ex: The photoelectric effect cannot be explained by the classical wave theory of light but is successfully explained by its particle (photon) nature.

questions.q: X-rays are a type of:
questions.ex: X-rays are a form of high-energy electromagnetic radiation with wavelengths shorter than UV light.

questions.q: X-rays are commonly used in medical imaging because they can:
options: Penetrate soft tissues but are absorbed by bones
Be seen by the naked eye
questions.ex: X-rays penetrate soft tissues easily but are absorbed more by denser materials like bones, allowing for skeletal imaging.

questions.q: The acronym LASER stands for Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation. What is a key characteristic of laser light?
options: It is highly collimated and monochromatic
questions.ex: Laser light is highly collimated (travels in a narrow beam), monochromatic (single wavelength/color), and coherent (waves are in phase).

questions.q: Which process is fundamental to the operation of a laser?
questions.ex: Lasers work on the principle of stimulated emission, where an excited atom is stimulated to emit a photon by an incoming photon of the same energy.

questions.q: In X-ray production, what is the role of the high voltage applied across the X-ray tube?
questions.ex: The high voltage accelerates electrons towards the anode, where their collision produces X-rays.

questions.q: Materials with electrical conductivity between that of a conductor and an insulator are called:
questions.ex: Semiconductors have conductivities that lie between those of conductors and insulators.

questions.q: A diode is a semiconductor device that primarily allows current to flow in:
questions.ex: A diode acts as a one-way valve for current, allowing it to pass in one direction (forward bias) and blocking it in the opposite direction (reverse bias).

questions.q: Doping a semiconductor involves adding impurities to change its electrical conductivity. Adding a pentavalent impurity (like phosphorus) to silicon creates a(n):
questions.ex: Adding a pentavalent impurity (with 5 valence electrons) to a tetravalent semiconductor (like silicon) creates excess free electrons, making it an N-type semiconductor.

questions.q: A transistor is primarily used for:
questions.ex: Transistors are versatile semiconductor devices used for amplifying electronic signals and electrical power, or as switches.

questions.q: In a p-n junction diode, the depletion region is formed due to the recombination of:
questions.ex: The depletion region in a p-n junction is formed by the diffusion of electrons from the N-side to the P-side and holes from the P-side to the N-side, where they recombine.

questions.q: Which basic logic gate produces an output of 1 only when all its inputs are 1?
questions.ex: The AND gate's output is HIGH (1) only if all its inputs are HIGH (1).

questions.q: The output of a NOT gate is the ______ of its input.
questions.ex: A NOT gate (inverter) produces an output that is the logical complement (opposite) of its input.

questions.q: Which logic gate is known as a 'universal gate' because it can be used to construct all other logic gates?
questions.ex: Both NAND and NOR gates are considered universal gates because any other logic gate can be implemented using only NAND gates (or only NOR gates).

questions.q: If the inputs to an OR gate are 0 and 1, what is the output?
questions.ex: An OR gate produces an output of 1 if at least one of its inputs is 1. (0 OR 1 = 1).

questions.q: Which logic gate gives a true (1) output when its inputs are different?
questions.ex: An XOR (exclusive OR) gate produces an output of 1 if its inputs are different (one 0 and one 1), and 0 if they are the same.

questions.q: Signals that can take on any value within a continuous range are characteristic of:
questions.ex: Analog signals are continuous and can represent an infinite number of values within a range.

questions.q: Digital signals are typically represented by discrete values, most commonly:
questions.ex: Digital signals use discrete values, usually binary (0 and 1), represented by distinct voltage levels (e.g., HIGH/LOW or ON/OFF).

questions.q: Which of the following is an advantage of digital over analog electronics?
questions.ex: Digital signals are more robust against noise and interference because small variations in voltage do not change the intended binary value.

questions.q: An Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) transforms:
questions.ex: An ADC converts a continuous analog signal into a discrete digital signal.

questions.q: Which type of electronics is commonly used in modern computers and microcontrollers?
questions.ex: Modern computers and microcontrollers are based on digital electronics, processing information in binary format.

questions.q: What is the SI unit of mass?
questions.ex: The kilogram (kg) is the SI base unit of mass.

questions.q: The SI unit of time is the:
questions.ex: The second (s) is the SI base unit of time.

questions.q: Which of the following is the SI unit for electric current?
questions.ex: The Ampere (A) is the SI base unit of electric current.

questions.q: What is the SI unit of luminous intensity?
questions.ex: The candela (cd) is the SI base unit of luminous intensity.

questions.q: Which of the following is a derived SI unit?
questions.ex: The Newton (N) is a derived unit (kg·m/s²) used for force, while meter, kilogram, and Kelvin are base units.

questions.q: The dimension of velocity is:
questions.ex: Velocity is displacement per unit time, so its dimension is Length/Time or [LT⁻¹].

questions.q: What are the dimensions of force?
questions.ex: Force (F) = mass (M) × acceleration (LT⁻²), so its dimensions are [MLT⁻²].

questions.q: If an equation is dimensionally consistent, it means:
options: All terms have the same units
All terms have the same dimensions
questions.ex: Dimensional consistency requires that all terms in an equation have the same fundamental dimensions (e.g., [L], [M], [T]).

questions.q: What are the dimensions of energy?
questions.ex: Energy (e.g., kinetic energy = ½mv²) has dimensions of mass (M) × velocity² ([LT⁻¹]²) = [ML²T⁻²].

questions.q: Dimensional analysis can be used to check the ______ of a physical equation.
questions.ex: Dimensional analysis is used to check the dimensional consistency of an equation, which is a necessary but not sufficient condition for its correctness.

questions.q: The closeness of a measured value to the true value is called:
questions.ex: Accuracy refers to how close a measurement is to the true or accepted value.

questions.q: The closeness of agreement between independent measurements obtained under the same conditions is called:
questions.ex: Precision refers to the reproducibility of measurements, i.e., how close repeated measurements are to each other.

questions.q: Which type of error is caused by unpredictable fluctuations in experimental conditions and affects precision?
questions.ex: Random errors are unpredictable and vary from one measurement to the next, typically affecting the precision of measurements.

questions.q: An error that consistently shifts measurements in one direction from the true value is a:
questions.ex: Systematic errors are biases in measurement that consistently cause the measured value to be too high or too low.

questions.q: The smallest division or reading that an instrument can show is its:
questions.ex: The least count of an instrument is the smallest value that can be measured by it, representing its resolution.

questions.q: How many significant figures are there in the number 0.0050?
questions.ex: Leading zeros (0.00) are not significant. Trailing zeros after a decimal point (50) are significant. So, 2 significant figures.

questions.q: Round the number 2.356 to two significant figures.
questions.ex: The third significant figure is 5, and it is followed by 6 (which is >5), so round up the second significant figure. 2.356 rounds to 2.4.

questions.q: How many significant figures are in 1200 if the trailing zeros are not meant to be significant?
questions.ex: Unless a decimal point is present or explicitly stated, trailing zeros in a whole number are not significant. So, 1 and 2 are significant, making 2 significant figures.

questions.q: When adding or subtracting measurements, the result should be rounded to the same number of decimal places as the measurement with the ______ decimal places.
questions.ex: The rule for addition/subtraction with significant figures is to round the result to the fewest decimal places found in any of the original measurements.

questions.q: When multiplying or dividing measurements, the result should be rounded to the same number of significant figures as the measurement with the ______ significant figures.
questions.ex: The rule for multiplication/division with significant figures is to round the result to the fewest significant figures found in any of the original measurements.

questions.q: A fluid is a substance that can flow and assumes the shape of its container. Which states of matter are considered fluids?
questions.ex: Both liquids and gases are considered fluids as they can flow and take the shape of their container.

questions.q: The mass per unit volume of a substance is called its:
questions.ex: Density (ρ) = Mass (m) / Volume (V).

questions.q: Which property of fluids describes their resistance to flow?
questions.ex: Viscosity is a measure of a fluid's resistance to flow.

questions.q: What is the SI unit of pressure?
questions.ex: The SI unit of pressure is the Pascal (Pa), which is equivalent to N/m².

questions.q: In an incompressible fluid, an increase in pressure at one point causes an equal increase in pressure at every other point in the fluid. This is known as:
questions.ex: Pascal's Law states that a pressure change at any point in a confined incompressible fluid is transmitted throughout the fluid such that the same change occurs everywhere.

questions.q: Pressure is defined as force per unit:
questions.ex: Pressure (P) = Force (F) / Area (A).

questions.q: A hydraulic lift works on the principle of:
questions.ex: Hydraulic systems, including lifts, use Pascal's Law to multiply force.

questions.q: The atmospheric pressure at sea level is approximately:
questions.ex: Standard atmospheric pressure at sea level is approximately 101,325 Pascals (or 1 atmosphere).

questions.q: In a fluid at rest, the pressure at a given depth depends on the:
options: Depth and density of the fluid
questions.ex: Pressure in a fluid at rest is given by P = ρgh, where ρ is density, g is acceleration due to gravity, and h is depth.

questions.q: Which instrument is used to measure atmospheric pressure?
questions.ex: A barometer is an instrument used to measure atmospheric pressure.

questions.q: The upward force exerted by a fluid that opposes the weight of an immersed object is called:
questions.ex: Buoyant force is the upward force exerted by a fluid that opposes the weight of a partially or fully immersed object.

questions.q: Archimedes' Principle states that the buoyant force on an object is equal to the:
options: Mass of the fluid displaced by the object
Weight of the fluid displaced by the object
questions.ex: Archimedes' Principle states that the buoyant force on a submerged object is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object.

questions.q: An object floats in a fluid if its average density is ______ the density of the fluid.
questions.ex: An object floats if its average density is less than or equal to the density of the fluid it is in.

questions.q: A block of wood floats on water, while a stone sinks. This is because:
options: Wood is less dense than water
questions.ex: Wood floats because its average density is less than the density of water, while stone sinks because its density is greater than water.

questions.q: If an object is fully submerged and its weight is equal to the buoyant force, the object will:
questions.ex: If the buoyant force equals the weight of the object, it will be in equilibrium and remain suspended at whatever depth it is placed.

questions.q: Bernoulli's Principle states that as the speed of a fluid increases, its pressure:
questions.ex: Bernoulli's Principle describes the inverse relationship between the speed and pressure of a fluid. As fluid speed increases, its pressure decreases.

questions.q: Which of the following is an application of Bernoulli's Principle?
questions.ex: Airplane wings (airfoils) are shaped to create a difference in air speed above and below the wing, leading to lower pressure above and thus lift, based on Bernoulli's principle.

questions.q: A venturi meter is used to measure the ______ of a fluid in a pipe, based on Bernoulli's principle.
questions.ex: A venturi meter measures flow rate by detecting the pressure drop that occurs as fluid speeds up through a constricted section, consistent with Bernoulli's principle.

questions.q: According to Bernoulli's principle, an ideal fluid's total energy (pressure energy + kinetic energy + potential energy) along a streamline remains:
questions.ex: Bernoulli's principle is a statement of the conservation of energy for an ideal fluid in steady flow.

questions.q: The curveball in baseball utilizes which principle to achieve its spin-induced curve?
questions.ex: The Magnus Effect, which causes a spinning object to deviate from its straight trajectory in a fluid, is a direct consequence of Bernoulli's principle and differences in air pressure around the spinning object.

questions.q: The property of a material to return to its original shape after being deformed is called:
questions.ex: Elasticity is the ability of a body to resist a distorting influence or stress and to return to its original size and shape when the stress is removed.

questions.q: Stress is defined as ______ per unit area.
questions.ex: Stress (σ) is the internal resisting force per unit cross-sectional area within a deformable body.

questions.q: Strain is defined as the fractional change in ______ caused by stress.
questions.ex: Strain (ε) is the deformation of a material in response to stress, expressed as a fractional change in dimension (e.g., change in length/original length).

questions.q: Within the elastic limit, stress is directly proportional to strain. This statement is known as:
questions.ex: Hooke's Law states that for an elastic body, the deformation produced is directly proportional to the applied force (or stress is proportional to strain).

questions.q: Young's Modulus is a measure of a material's:
questions.ex: Young's Modulus (E) is a measure of the stiffness of an elastic material, defined as the ratio of stress to strain in a material's elastic range.

questions.q: The phenomenon that causes the surface of a liquid to behave like a stretched elastic membrane is called:
questions.ex: Surface tension is the cohesive force that acts on the surface of a liquid, causing it to minimize its surface area and behave like a stretched film.

questions.q: Surface tension is caused by the ______ forces between liquid molecules at the surface.
questions.ex: Surface tension arises from the imbalanced cohesive forces (attraction between like molecules) acting on molecules at the surface compared to those in the bulk of the liquid.

questions.q: Which of the following decreases the surface tension of water?
questions.ex: Detergents (surfactants) reduce the surface tension of water, allowing it to wet surfaces more effectively.

questions.q: The ability of a liquid to flow in narrow spaces against the force of gravity (e.g., water rising in a thin tube) is due to:
questions.ex: Capillary action, which is responsible for this phenomenon, is a result of the combined effects of surface tension and adhesive forces between the liquid and the tube walls.

questions.q: Water droplets tend to be spherical in shape primarily due to:
questions.ex: Surface tension tries to minimize the surface area of a liquid, and for a given volume, a sphere has the smallest surface area.

questions.q: Viscosity is a measure of a fluid's resistance to:
questions.ex: Viscosity describes the internal friction of a fluid, or its resistance to flow or shear deformation.

questions.q: The SI unit of viscosity is the Pascal-second (Pa·s), also known as the:
questions.ex: The Pascal-second (Pa·s) is the SI unit, and one Pa·s equals 10 Poise (P) or 1000 centipoise (cP).

questions.q: As temperature increases, the viscosity of most liquids generally:
questions.ex: For most liquids, intermolecular forces weaken with increasing temperature, leading to decreased viscosity.

questions.q: Which of the following fluids would typically have the highest viscosity?
questions.ex: Honey is much thicker and flows much slower than water, alcohol, or air, indicating a higher viscosity.

questions.q: The drag force experienced by an object moving through a viscous fluid is described by:
questions.ex: Stokes' Law describes the viscous drag force on a small spherical particle moving through a viscous fluid.

questions.q: Which of the following types of electromagnetic radiation has the longest wavelength?
questions.ex: The electromagnetic spectrum in order of increasing wavelength (decreasing frequency/energy) is Gamma, X-ray, UV, Visible, IR, Microwave, Radio.

questions.q: Which part of the electromagnetic spectrum is visible to the human eye?
questions.ex: Visible light occupies a small portion of the electromagnetic spectrum that our eyes can detect.

questions.q: All electromagnetic waves travel at the speed of light in a vacuum, which is approximately:
questions.ex: The speed of light in a vacuum (c) is approximately 3.0 x 10⁸ m/s.

questions.q: Which electromagnetic waves are used in remote controls and thermal imaging cameras?
questions.ex: Infrared (IR) radiation is used in remote controls and is detected by thermal imaging cameras.

questions.q: Which electromagnetic waves are responsible for sunburn and can cause skin cancer?
questions.ex: Ultraviolet (UV) radiation is known to cause sunburn and contribute to skin cancer.

questions.q: The speed of a wave is determined by the product of its wavelength and its:
questions.ex: Wave speed (v) = Wavelength (λ) × Frequency (f).

questions.q: When a wave passes from a denser medium to a rarer medium, its speed generally:
questions.ex: Waves generally speed up when passing from a denser to a rarer medium (e.g., light from glass to air).

questions.q: Which type of wave propagates through the oscillation of particles in a medium, transferring energy but not matter?
questions.ex: Mechanical waves propagate by causing oscillations of the particles of the medium, transferring energy without transferring matter.

questions.q: The maximum displacement of a wave particle from its equilibrium position is called its:
questions.ex: Amplitude is the maximum displacement or distance moved by a point on a vibrating body or wave measured from its equilibrium position.

questions.q: A standing wave is formed when two waves of the same frequency, amplitude, and wavelength traveling in opposite directions:
questions.ex: Standing waves are formed by the superposition of two identical waves moving in opposite directions.

questions.q: Radio waves are primarily used for:
questions.ex: Radio waves are used for broadcasting radio and television signals, as well as in various wireless communication technologies.

questions.q: Microwaves are commonly used in:
questions.ex: Microwaves are used in radar for detection and ranging, and in microwave ovens for heating food.

questions.q: Ultraviolet (UV) radiation has applications in:
questions.ex: UV light is used for sterilization (killing germs) and in forensic science (detecting bodily fluids, counterfeit currency).

questions.q: Gamma rays are used in medicine for:
options: Cancer therapy and sterilization of medical equipment
questions.ex: Gamma rays are used in radiotherapy to kill cancer cells and for sterilizing medical instruments due to their high penetrating power.

questions.q: Infrared (IR) radiation is widely used in:
questions.ex: IR radiation is used in night vision devices, thermal cameras, and remote controls because objects emit IR based on their temperature.

questions.q: One of the postulates of Einstein's Special Theory of Relativity states that the laws of physics are the same for all observers in:
questions.ex: The first postulate of special relativity states that the laws of physics are invariant (identical) in all inertial (non-accelerating) frames of reference.

questions.q: The second postulate of Special Relativity states that the speed of light in a vacuum is the same for all inertial observers, regardless of the motion of the source or the observer. What is a consequence of this?
questions.ex: The constancy of the speed of light leads directly to the concepts of time dilation, length contraction, and the relativity of simultaneity, demonstrating that space and time are interconnected.

questions.q: According to Special Relativity, as an object's speed approaches the speed of light, its mass appears to:
questions.ex: Relativistic mass increases as an object's speed approaches the speed of light.

questions.q: What is the primary concept challenged by Special Relativity regarding simultaneity?
options: Events occurring at different places can be simultaneous for all observers
Events occurring at the same place are always simultaneous for all observers
Simultaneity is absolute and independent of the observer's motion
Simultaneity is relative and depends on the observer's frame of reference
questions.ex: Special Relativity asserts that simultaneity is not absolute; events simultaneous for one observer may not be simultaneous for another observer in relative motion.

questions.q: Which phenomenon is predicted by Special Relativity?
questions.ex: Time dilation is a direct consequence of special relativity, where time passes more slowly for an object moving relative to an observer.

questions.q: Time dilation implies that a clock moving relative to an observer will appear to run ______ compared to a stationary clock.
questions.ex: According to time dilation, clocks in motion relative to an observer tick slower than stationary clocks.

questions.q: Length contraction implies that an object moving relative to an observer will appear ______ in the direction of motion.
questions.ex: Length contraction causes an object's length to appear shorter when it is moving at relativistic speeds relative to an observer, but only in the direction of motion.

questions.q: For time dilation and length contraction to be significant, an object must be moving at speeds comparable to:
options: The speed of a jet plane
questions.ex: These relativistic effects become noticeable only at speeds approaching the speed of light.

questions.q: The proper time (Δt₀) is the time interval measured by a clock that is:
options: At rest relative to the event
questions.ex: Proper time is the time interval between two events measured by an observer who is at rest with respect to both events.

questions.q: If a spaceship travels at 0.8c (80% the speed of light), how will its length appear to a stationary observer on Earth?
questions.ex: Due to length contraction, the spaceship will appear shorter to the Earth observer in the direction of its motion.

questions.q: The famous equation E=mc² relates:
questions.ex: E=mc² is Einstein's mass-energy equivalence formula, stating that mass and energy are interchangeable.

questions.q: In the equation E=mc², 'c' represents the:
questions.ex: 'c' stands for the speed of light in a vacuum.

questions.q: Nuclear reactions (fission and fusion) release enormous amounts of energy. This energy comes from:
options: Conversion of a small amount of mass into energy
questions.ex: In nuclear reactions, a small amount of mass is converted into a large amount of energy according to E=mc² (mass defect).

questions.q: If 1 kg of mass could be completely converted into energy, how much energy would be produced?
questions.ex: E = mc² = 1 kg * (3 x 10⁸ m/s)² = 9 x 10¹⁶ J (Note: the options have one more 10, so 9 x 10^17 is wrong for 1kg of mass converted to energy. Let me correct the explanation and answer). For simplicity, I will rephrase it with a smaller number or correct the value for 1kg.

questions.q: The concept of mass-energy equivalence is a cornerstone of:
questions.ex: Mass-energy equivalence is a central concept in Einstein's Special Theory of Relativity.

questions.q: Which technique is used to separate insoluble solids from liquids using gravity?
questions.ex: Filtration involves passing a mixture through a filter medium to separate insoluble solids from liquids.

questions.q: When heating a liquid in a test tube, the test tube should be pointed:
questions.ex: Always point a heated test tube away from yourself and others to prevent injury from boiling over or splashing.

questions.q: What is the purpose of calibration in laboratory measurements?
options: To increase the speed of measurement
To ensure accuracy and reliability of measurements
To reduce the cost of instruments
questions.ex: Calibration is the process of comparing a measuring instrument's readings to a known standard to ensure its accuracy and reliability.

questions.q: Which piece of laboratory equipment is used for precisely measuring the volume of a liquid?
questions.ex: A volumetric flask is designed to measure a precise, fixed volume of liquid, making it suitable for preparing solutions of known concentrations.

questions.q: What is the first step in handling a chemical spill in the lab?
options: Clean it up immediately with a cloth
Evacuate the area and notify the supervisor
Try to identify the chemical by smelling it
questions.ex: In case of a chemical spill, the immediate priority is safety: evacuate the area and inform the supervisor or emergency personnel.

questions.q: Which instrument is used to measure electric current?
questions.ex: An ammeter is designed to measure electric current in a circuit.

questions.q: A Vernier caliper is used to measure:
questions.ex: A Vernier caliper is a precision instrument used for measuring small lengths, such as diameter, depth, or internal dimensions, with greater accuracy than a ruler.

questions.q: What does a galvanometer measure?
questions.ex: A galvanometer is an electromechanical instrument for detecting and indicating electric current. It can be converted into an ammeter or voltmeter.

questions.q: Which device is used to measure the potential difference between two points in a circuit?
questions.ex: A voltmeter is connected in parallel to measure the voltage (potential difference) across a component.

questions.q: A balance scale is used to measure:
questions.ex: A balance scale measures mass by comparing an unknown mass to known masses.

questions.q: The uncertainty in a measurement represents the range within which the true value is expected to lie. It is often expressed as a:
questions.ex: Uncertainty is commonly expressed as ± an absolute value (e.g., 5.0 ± 0.1 cm) or as a percentage (e.g., 5.0 cm ± 2%).

questions.q: Errors due to faulty calibration of an instrument or incorrect methodology are classified as:
questions.ex: Systematic errors are predictable, consistent errors that arise from flaws in the experimental design, equipment, or procedure (e.g., a miscalibrated balance).

questions.q: Which of the following would help reduce random errors in an experiment?
options: Repeating measurements and taking an average
questions.ex: Repeating measurements and calculating the average helps to minimize the effect of random fluctuations, thus improving precision.

questions.q: An example of a personal error in an experiment would be:
options: Incorrectly reading a scale due to parallax
An unknown impurity in a chemical
questions.ex: Personal errors are human mistakes, such as misreading an instrument (parallax error), incorrect judgment, or carelessness.

questions.q: To minimize the percentage uncertainty in a measurement, one should aim for a measurement with a ______ value.
questions.ex: For a fixed absolute uncertainty, a larger measured value will result in a smaller percentage uncertainty (Percentage Uncertainty = (Absolute Uncertainty / Measured Value) × 100%).
